author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Whether Oscar-Nominated or Not, Black Actresses Will Throw Their Own Party
description: At two events during Oscar week, these stars spoke candidly about an awards season that sometimes excludes them.
content: On Wednesday night, at a house party high in the Hollywood Hills, Alfre Woodard was trying to gather some of the world’s most talented black actresses for a group picture.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 8, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 8, 2020.
content: A political memo on Friday about President Trump’s remarks at the White House the day after his acquittal misstated the year of a shooting that gravely wounded Representative Steve Scalise, Republican of Louisiana. It was 2017, not 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Finding an Aesthetic in the ‘Year of Africa’
description: 17 African countries declared independence in 1960. Archival photographs capture the mood of the period 60 years later.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French Ice Sports Chief Resigns Amid Sexual Abuse Scandal
description: Didier Gailhaguet stepped down after allegations of rape and sexual harassment against underage figure skaters by their coaches while he was in charge of the federation.
content: PARIS — The president of the French Federation of Ice Sports, Didier Gailhaguet, said on Saturday that he had resigned after allegations of sexual abuse of underage figure skaters by their coaches that have prompted a broader reckoning across other sports in France.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Former C.E.O. Sentenced to Nine Months in Admissions Case
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 8, 2020.
content: “There is no term in the English language that describes your conduct as well as the Yiddish term of chutzpah.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Analysis of the Feb. 7 New Hampshire Debate
description: Here is how our reporters covered the Feb. 7 debate in real time from New Hampshire, four days before the primary.
content: Here is how our reporters covered the Feb. 7 debate in real time from New Hampshire, four days before the primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Baylor to Suspend 14 Baseball Players Because of a Hazing Incident
description: The suspensions — based on an incident from last year — will be staggered over three weeks, starting with the season opener next Friday. Each player involved will be suspended two games apiece.
content: WACO, Texas — Baylor University will suspend 14 baseball players during the upcoming season because of a hazing incident from last year, school officials announced Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! How Do I Get Out of Resort Fees?
description: In this week’s column, Sarah Firshein investigates those pesky resort fees — and ways to perhaps get out of them.
content: I love The New York Edition — I’ve stayed there three times in the past year. What I hate is the destination fee — $35 per room per night — that includes credit toward the bar, spa and laundry. We traveled with our 16 and 18 year olds in April; their room was charged the fee even though they couldn’t possibly use the bar. I have got the fee refunded twice, but hate having to fight with them every time we check out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mathew Silver
title: A Volleyball Star Who Raps as Kofi
description: Daenan Gyimah, who plays for the U.C.L.A. Bruins, is also a rising hip-hop artist.
content: Name: Daenan Gyimah
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Orson Bean, Free-Spirited Actor of Stage and Screen, Dies at 91
description: After finding success on television and Broadway, he established a progressive school and later wandered around America as a late-blooming hippie.
content: Orson Bean, the free-spirited television, stage and film comedian who stepped out of his storybook life to found a progressive school, move to Australia, give away his possessions and wander around a turbulent America in the 1970s as a late-blooming hippie, was killed in a traffic accident on Friday in Venice, Calif. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best of New York Fashion Week, in Pictures
description: The fall 2020 shows are underway in New York — and T’s photographers are there to capture it all.
content: The fall 2020 shows are underway in New York — and T’s photographers are there to capture it all. We’ll be updating this post daily with notes on the collections and our favorite images, so remember to check back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Cooper Hewitt Director Abruptly Resigns
description: The design museum did not say why Caroline Baumann stepped down. The Smithsonian provost will serve as interim director during the search for her replacement.
content: Caroline Baumann, the director of the Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian Design Museum in Manhattan, abruptly stepped down on Friday, a museum spokeswoman confirmed in an email.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Finding an Aesthetic in the ‘Year of Africa’
description: 17 African countries declared independence in 1960. Archival photographs capture the mood of the period 60 years later.

content: PARIS — The president of the French Federation of Ice Sports, Didier Gailhaguet, said on Saturday that he had resigned after allegations of sexual abuse of underage figure skaters by their coaches that have prompted a broader reckoning across other sports in France.

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Orson Bean, Free-Spirited Actor of Stage and Screen, Dies at 91
description: After finding success on television and Broadway, he established a progressive school and later wandered around America as a late-blooming hippie.
content: Orson Bean, the free-spirited television, stage and film comedian who stepped out of his storybook life to found a progressive school, move to Australia, give away his possessions and wander around a turbulent America in the 1970s as a late-blooming hippie, was killed in a traffic accident on Friday in Venice, Calif. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Clifford Krauss
title: To Survive, Venezuela’s Leader Gives Up Decades of Control Over Oil
description: Faced with a severe economic crisis, the country’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, is letting foreign firms take over daily operations of its oil fields. It’s a break with core tenets of his socialist revolution.
content: CARACAS, Venezuela — After decades of dominating its oil industry, the Venezuelan government is quietly surrendering control to foreign companies in a desperate bid to keep the economy afloat and hold on to power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Audit Finds Suspicious Financial Dealings in African Soccer
description: An investigation into the Confederation of African Football uncovered information suggesting that tens of millions of dollars had been misappropriated.
content: An audit of the governing body for soccer in Africa has uncovered millions of dollars of financial irregularities, a development that threatens to bring down its leadership after more than a year of turmoil at the troubled organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Why Voting Discrimination Haunts America
description: The 15th Amendment had a major flaw.
content: A momentous anniversary in American history came and went this week, almost unnoticed: The 15th Amendment to the Constitution, which prohibits denying or abridging the right to vote on the basis of race, was ratified 150 years ago, on Feb. 3, 1870.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Government Uses ‘Near Perfect Surveillance’ Data on Americans
description: Congressional hearings are urgently needed to address location tracking.
content: “When the government tracks the location of a cellphone it achieves near perfect surveillance, as if it had attached an ankle monitor to the phone’s user,” wrote John Roberts, the chief justice of the Supreme Court, in a 2018 ruling that prevented the government from obtaining location data from cellphone towers without a warrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Widmer
title: What Will the Next Decade Bring? The 1920s Offer an Answer
description: It has been a long time since the winter of 1920, but the old fault lines are still visible.
content: A year ago, The Times introduced a series of essays about the transformative year 1919, beginning with F. Scott Fitzgerald’s observation, in his essay “The Crack-Up,” that a first-rate intelligence could hold two opposed ideas at the same time. That seemed a fitting way to assess the United States at a pivotal moment, with half the country rushing headlong into the Jazz Age and the other half trying to turn back the clock toward simpler times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Part of America Is Still Forgotten, Now Under Trump
description: The economy may get the president re-elected, but not everyone is sharing in its strength.
content: President Trump declared in his State of the Union address that “our economy is the best it has ever been.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathy Tempelsman
title: ‘1917’ Turns a Horrific War Into an Uplifting Hero’s Journey
description: World War I was a disaster, but Sam Mendes’s Oscar-nominated epic paints a dangerously misleading picture of the conflict.
content: I was looking forward to seeing Sam Mendes’s film “1917” when it arrived in theaters in December. I have a special interest in the subject — my grandfather fought in World War I, and I’ve done years of research on the events while writing a play about the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Two American Soldiers Killed in Shootout With Afghan Forces
description: Six American service members were wounded, a spokesman for the U.S. military said. He said a person in an Afghan uniform appeared to have opened fire.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A shootout between Afghan and American soldiers during joint operations in eastern Afghanistan on Saturday resulted in deaths on both sides, with two Americans killed, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Whether Oscar-Nominated or Not, Black Actresses Will Throw Their Own Party
description: At two events during Oscar week, these stars spoke candidly about an awards season that sometimes excludes them.

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Trump Reprises State of the Union Message in North Carolina
description: The president promoted the economy and “opportunity zones” and questioned African-American support for Democrats.
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Three days after his State of the Union address, President Trump traveled on Friday to North Carolina to drive home one of the speech’s major themes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Andrew J. Ries has a few new experiments, and we are his subjects.
content: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’m declaring 2020 the year of cryptic puzzles, all sorts, especially for those of you with a full year or more of standard crossword grids under your belts. They are witty and interesting, what you would get if you pulled all of the pun clues out of several standard puzzles and combined them. Solving Puns and Anagrams puzzles, or PandAs, is a great way to make the transition to cryptic puzzles from standard crosswords because they contain elements of both. They are also a total blast in their own right — once you get into them, you’ll never skip them again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: New Report on 138 Coronavirus Cases Reveals Disturbing Details
description: A highly contagious patient, virus transmission inside a hospital and unexpected turns for the worse have emerged as part of the epidemic in China.
content: One patient, admitted to a hospital in Wuhan, China, infected at least 10 health care workers and four other patients with the coronavirus that has sickened more than 34,000 people, killed 700 and reached two dozen other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Politics Plays Out in Textbooks
description: Readers react to an article comparing textbooks in California and Texas.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: How 2020 Democrats Plan to Deal With Trump’s Remade Judiciary
description: The Trump administration has reshaped the courts through conservative judicial appointments. Here’s how presidential candidates promised to respond.
content: CONCORD, N.H. — Though an impeachment trial, a Russia investigation, an Iran crisis and other daily turmoil, President Trump has repeatedly been able to point to one consistent success that has united Republicans — moving conservative justices onto all levels of the federal judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Post Impeachment, a Key Republican Suburban Area Rallies Around Trump
description: Voters in the populous, heavily Republican suburbs west of Milwaukee did not entirely embrace Donald Trump in 2016. They do now.
content: WAUKESHA, Wis. — The moment President Trump was acquitted in the Senate this week, Judy Ryan was licking a blueberry ice cream cone in the Brookfield Square shopping mall and feeling happy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Wobbly After Iowa, Biden Confronts a Perilous Moment
description: A weak showing in New Hampshire, some Democrats warn, could undermine his electability argument and accelerate a flight of donors and voters to his rivals.
content: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s fourth-place finish in Iowa and his wobbly standing here in New Hampshire are now testing the central premise of his candidacy — that he is the Democrat with the strongest chance to defeat President Trump — and forcing his team to scramble to prove that claim before voters move on to other candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Sarah Mervosh and Miriam Jordan
title: ‘Helicopter Went Down, Flames Seen’: Kobe Bryant’s Last Flight
description: Eight passengers and a pilot were on the S-76B helicopter that crashed on a foggy hillside in the Santa Monica Mountains. This is the story of what happened.
content: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant pulled his Range Rover into the familiar lot on the edge of Orange County’s John Wayne Airport, the quiet side where small charter planes and private helicopters whisk people into the sky above the congestion of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Deaths in China From Coronavirus Reach 811, Surpassing SARS Toll
description: The number of confirmed infections rose to 37,198, most of them in Hubei Province, Chinese officials said on Sunday.
content: [This briefing has ended. Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Don Strikes Back
description: An enraged and ebullient Trump ups the body count.
content: Democrats: The only thing you have to fear is Trump himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Donald Trump Theory of Bernie Sanders
description: What better foe for the president than his alter ego?
content: A Republican friend of mine rolled his eyes (and maybe even licked his chops) at the possibility that Democrats would nominate Bernie Sanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: Where’s Xi? China’s Leader Commands Coronavirus Fight From Safe Heights
description: Xi Jinping has backed out of the spotlight as the country faces its worst crisis in years, reflecting the political risks he faces if efforts to contain the virus fail.
content: WUHAN, China — President Xi Jinping strode onstage before an adoring audience in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing less than three weeks ago, trumpeting his successes in steering China through a tumultuous year and promising “landmark” progress in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Almukhtar, Quoctrung Bui and Weiyi Cai
title: Which Candidates Got the Most Speaking Time in the Democratic Debate
description: Senator Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. led the stage of seven candidates.Follow along live during the debate.
content: Senator Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. led the stage of seven candidates.Follow along live during the debate.

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Impeachment Briefing: Impeachment’s Legacy
description: In the final edition of our impeachment newsletter, a survey of the trial’s impact on American politics.
content: This newsletter spent a lot of time thinking about the politicians and officials responsible for conducting, participating in and judging the impeachment inquiry and trial. One of those officials, Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman — a member of the National Security Council — was escorted from the White House today, most likely as an act of retribution for his testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 100 of Our Best Chocolate Recipes
description: Chocolate caramel tart, blender chocolate mousse, and more recipes.
content: Looking for a special dessert for Valentine’s Day (or any day)? Chocolate lava cake for two (above), skillet brownie with chocolate ganache frosting, chocolate-bourbon truffles or any of the recipes in the collection below will be perfect. Check out more of our best Valentine’s Day recipes here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can I Pay Less Rent if My Roommates Are Slobs?
description: Everyone is entitled to live in a space where they feel comfortable. But they also shouldn’t have to feel pressured to do chores they don’t want to do.
content: Q: I am a professional in my mid-20s, subletting a room in an Astoria apartment. My two roommates, who are on the lease, leave their dirty dishes in the sink and on the stove for days, and ignore my requests to clean up. The last time I asked, one roommate told me she doesn’t like being told what to do. Their mess makes the kitchen essentially unusable. Yet, I’m still paying rent for the common area. I’m planning to move out, but in the meantime, can I ask them to reduce my rent in exchange for forfeiting use of the kitchen?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Raftery
title: ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood,’ Many Times Over
description: The New Beverly Cinema, owned by Quentin Tarantino, is riding a boom in art house theaters.
content: LOS ANGELES — On a crisp Saturday night last month, a hundred movie lovers got into their cars and drove to the New Beverly Cinema, an old theater on Beverly Boulevard, to relive a golden age of Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Jeff Sessions Was ‘Trump Before Trump.’ Will Alabama Voters Remember?
description: Ask Republicans in the state what they think of Mr. Sessions, who is running again for the Senate there, and many will use the same belittling adjectives the president has hurled at him.
content: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — It was another era, in another Republican Party. Jeff Sessions was a backbench senator from Alabama who defied the Republican president and doomed a bipartisan immigration bill with claims it would let terrorists and child molesters pour across the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: They Fight Suicide Bombers. But Can Afghan Police Fight Crime?
description: During a lull in terrorist attacks, Kabul residents are talking about how rampant crime has become. A long-militarized police force is finding it difficult to regear.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Here is a meme that briefly made the rounds on Afghan social media: “Breaking news,” it reads. “A suicide bomber has been robbed by thieves in Kabul. The thieves took from him his suicide vest, the detonators, and 2,000 afghanis.” (About $25.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. Women’s Team Qualifies for Olympic Soccer Tournament
description: The Americans, the reigning World Cup champions, will look to claim their fifth Olympic crown at the Tokyo Games this summer.
content: CARSON, Calif. — The United States women’s national team, starting 10 of the 11 players that delivered a victory in the Women’s World Cup final last July, clinched a berth in the Tokyo Olympics with a 4-0 win over Mexico on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Edward Wong
title: First American Dies of Coronavirus, Raising Questions About U.S. Response
description: The United States has no plans to conduct additional evacuations from China though some Americans are asking for help.
content: SHANGHAI — A United States citizen died from the coronavirus in Wuhan, China, American officials said on Saturday. It was the first known American death from the illness, and was likely to add to diplomatic friction over Beijing’s response to the epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner and Joel Petterson
title: Enjoy ‘The Irishman’? Baseball Offers Much of the Same, 162 Times a Year.
description: Long tangents. Short bursts of action. Cameos. And a lot of tedious watching.
content: “The Irishman” has been lauded as one of celebrated director Martin Scorsese’s greatest achievements, earning 10 Academy Award nominations. But for all the praise the movie has received, perhaps its most polarizing aspect has been its length. At 3 hours 29 minutes, it is 1 hour 40 minutes longer than one of its fellow best picture nominees, “Jojo Rabbit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Lonely Are the Brave
description: With his impeachment vote, Mitt Romney vindicates an American ideal.
content: To honor the memory of Kirk Douglas, who died this week at 103, I watched “Lonely Are the Brave” on Thursday night. The 1962 classic is about a 20th-century cowboy at mortal odds with modern life — a roaming spirit who won’t be stopped by wire fences, prison bars, search helicopters or sadistic lawmen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Rush Limbaugh in His Own Words
description: A collection of comments from the latest recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
content: During his third State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Trump presented the country’s highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, to the longtime conservative commentator Rush Limbaugh, who recently announced he has late-stage lung cancer. Past recipients of the award include Elie Wiesel, Rosa Parks and Mother Teresa. Mr. Trump told Mr. Limbaugh he was being recognized for “the millions of people a day that you speak to and that you inspire.” Millions more have perhaps never listened to his popular radio program. For those who haven’t, here is a selection of his comments on various issues:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 16-Year-Old Pleads Guilty to Murder in Colorado School Shooting
description: Alec McKinney, one of two students charged in the attack, told the authorities he had targeted people who had taunted him for being transgender.
content: A 16-year-old student who told the authorities that he was bullied because he was transgender pleaded guilty on Friday to first-degree murder in a school shooting outside Denver last year that killed one student and injured eight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono, Ryn Jirenuwat, Richard C. Paddock and Damien Cave
title: Soldier Kills 26 in Thailand Shooting Spree and Dies in Standoff
description: The soldier shot a superior officer at a military base, then went on a shooting rampage at a mall before he died in the standoff with soldiers and the police, officials said.
content: KORAT, Thailand — A soldier armed with an assault rifle went on a shooting rampage at a military base and a shopping mall in Thailand on Saturday, killing at least 26 people, wounding 57 and posting video on Facebook Live, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Monse: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Monse: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Monse: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Connection Before the Coffee Was Cold
description: Rolake Bamgbose and Justice Whitaker, both filmmakers, met through a dating app. Their first date was at a coffee shop.
content: Rolake Bamgbose and Justice Whitaker, filmmakers from the West Coast, sat across from each other at a coffee shop in Brooklyn, engrossed in conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: A Horse Has 5 Toes, and Then It Doesn’t
description: As a horse’s hoof forms, scientists say something profound is occurring in its anatomical development.
content: From the perspective of evolutionary and developmental biologists, a horse’s hoof is literally a giant middle finger. It seems to be the remnant of a foot that once had five full toes, with only three remaining visible — two vestigial digits are still on either side of the large, hardened middle digit, but there is no trace of the others. The hoof has been held up as a sterling example of the idea that if something isn’t working for a creature, it may be shed completely, with an excess toe or two left on the cutting room floor of evolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
title: Iowa in Disarray: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: It was a remarkably busy week on the 2020 campaign trail. Here’s a cheat sheet.
content: What a week. Let’s get right to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrice Peck
title: How to Build a Media Company
description: Take it from Jasmine Brand, who started the celebrity news site The Jasmine Brand 10 years ago, and is still going strong.
content: Years ago, Jasmine Brand wanted to stand out at red carpet events, so she settled on a tactic used by Hollywood stars: She transformed her hair. She dyed it a blazing hot pink to catch the attention of the people she wanted to interview for her recently created entertainment news blog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: For Runners, It’s Race Lottery Season
description: Feeling lucky? Two of the big race lotteries — actually drawings used to decide who gets to run in a race — are open right now.
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: Winners and Losers of the Democratic Debate
description: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
content: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Horse Girl’ and ‘Ma’
description: A new psychological thriller is available on Netflix. And an Octavia Spencer horror film is on HBO.
content: HORSE GIRL Stream on Netflix. Alison Brie — who co-wrote this film with its director, Jeff Baena — plays Sarah, an unassuming and socially awkward arts-and-crafts store employee who doesn’t quite fit in with her Zumba classmates or her roommate. Despite this, she finds comfort in her favorite TV show, “Purgatory,” and in visiting a horse she used to own — both of which seem to protect her from the world’s harsh realities, including her mother’s death and her grandmother’s psychosis. Then, Sarah begins to spiral. In what is a clear mental health decline, Sarah finds herself entangled in a web of amnesia, hallucinations and supernatural experiences. “It would be tactful, at this point, for ‘Horse Girl’ to show how Sarah’s hallucinations are causing her suffering; instead, it indulges them,” Natalia Winkelman wrote in her review for The New York Times. She added, “The more time we spend inside her visions, the more we are invited to enable her, to shrug off our worry in favor of an absorbing paranormal mystery.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nilo Tabrizy and Dmitriy Khavin
title: Highlights From the New Hampshire Democratic Debate
description: Seven presidential candidates faced off in New Hampshire, days before the Democratic primary.
content: Seven presidential candidates faced off in New Hampshire, days before the Democratic primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nilo Tabrizy and Dmitriy Khavin
title: Highlights From the New Hampshire Democratic Debate
description: Seven presidential candidates faced off in New Hampshire, days before the Democratic primary.
content: Seven presidential candidates faced off in New Hampshire, days before the Democratic primary.

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Who Won the New Hampshire Democratic Debate? Strategists Weigh In
description: A roundup of the Twitter reaction after seven candidates faced off Friday in New Hampshire.
content: Twitter can’t tell us whether, or how, Friday’s ABC News/WMUR Democratic debate might change voters’ minds. But it can give us the perspectives of some of the people with expertise on primary races: veteran campaign strategists and consultants from both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Mentors Named for Rolex Arts Initiative
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Spike Lee are among the artists who will pair with a protégé in the program.
content: CAPE TOWN — In the room where it happened (the Baxter Theater here), the composer and actor Lin-Manuel Miranda, the filmmaker Spike Lee, the visual artist Carrie Mae Weems and the theater director Phyllida Lloyd were announced on Saturday as the new mentors in the Rolex Mentor and Protégé Arts Initiative, which pairs eminent cultural figures with emerging artists in their fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Democrats Discuss Abortion Rights in Depth at Debate
description: The candidates had their most significant discussion about abortion in any debate yet, tackling an issue whose absence from previous debates has angered advocates.
content: In their most substantive debate statements to date on abortion, several of the leading Democratic presidential candidates reaffirmed on Friday night that if elected, they would put forward only Supreme Court nominees who supported Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision establishing a woman’s right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Amy Klobuchar Compares ‘Cool Newcomer’ Pete Buttigieg to Trump
description: Democrats were off to a fiery start in the New Hampshire presidential primary debate on Friday.
content: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota gave a fiery response at Friday’s debate to one of the most common lines of any presidential campaign: that voters want a new face, not a symbol of the old ways of Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Victors in Iowa, Sanders and Buttigieg Are Targets in Democratic Debate
description: In the most contentious debate so far, Joseph R. Biden Jr. challenged Bernie Sanders over gun regulation, and Amy Klobuchar accused Pete Buttigieg of presenting himself as a “cool newcomer.”
content: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The two victors in the Iowa caucuses, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and former Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., came under sharp and sustained criticism in a Democratic presidential debate on Friday, as their rivals tried to stop their momentum by assailing Mr. Sanders for his left-wing ideas and past opposition to gun control while targeting Mr. Buttigieg over his thin résumé and ties to big donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Katie Glueck
title: Biden Tells Voters to Look to the Past. (Just Not the Last Week.)
description: In New Hampshire, the Democratic field defines itself, unflatteringly, as “cool newcomer” vs. “establishment experience.”
content: MANCHESTER, N.H. — For months, he played the big-talking front-runner, swaggering if rarely steady, hoping voters would not linger long on the tautology of his premise: Joe Biden was the candidate who should win, he told fellow Democrats, because he was the candidate who could win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Joe Biden Attacks Bernie Sanders’s Record on Guns
description: Mr. Biden faulted Mr. Sanders for voting in favor of a 2005 bill to shield gun manufacturers from liability lawsuits. Mr. Biden said that the “first thing I’ll do as president is work to get rid of that.”
content: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday directly criticized Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont over his record on guns, drawing a sharp contrast with one of his top rivals on an issue that is important to many Democratic voters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tom Ford: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Tom Ford: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Tom Ford: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: The Picture Is Looking (a Little) Brighter for Women at the Oscars
description: Though their shutout from the directing nominations made headlines, female filmmakers dominate the documentary categories. And a female composer may win best score.
content: There’s been much ado about this year’s Oscar nominees for directing — a list devoid of any women for the second straight year. But in other categories honoring roles behind the camera, according to a new study, women are making some strides toward recognition from the academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: The Picture Is Looking (a Little) Brighter for Women at the Oscars
description: Though their shutout from the directing nominations made headlines, female filmmakers dominate the documentary categories. And a female composer may win best score.
content: There’s been much ado about this year’s Oscar nominees for directing — a list devoid of any women for the second straight year. But in other categories honoring roles behind the camera, according to a new study, women are making some strides toward recognition from the academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Fading of a Star
description: Neymar went to Paris to step out of Lionel Messi’s shadow, to live up to his billing as soccer’s next best thing. Nearly three years on, the move has been a comprehensive failure.
content: Enjoying this newsletter every week? Forward it to a friend and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni and Jonathan Martin
title: On Trump’s To-Do List: Take Back The Suburbs. Court Black Voters. Expand the Electoral Map. Win.
description: With impeachment behind the president, his re-election campaign wants to address political weaknesses exacerbated by his policies and behavior.
content: WASHINGTON — Buoyed by his impeachment acquittal and the muddled Democratic primary race, President Trump and his campaign are turning to address his re-election bid’s greatest weaknesses with an aggressive, well-funded but uncertain effort to win back suburban voters turned off by his policies and behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: ‘Innocent, but Implicated’: Wuhan Native Is in Limbo During Epidemic
description: Julie Zhong counts herself lucky. There has been little disruption to her life. But she’s angry about the prejudice she says people from her city are facing.
content: GUANGZHOU, China — For Julie Zhong, this Chinese New Year was supposed to be a time of transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: The Mystery of the Painting in Gallery 634
description: New evidence suggests a 17th-century work, on view for years at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was once owned by a Jewish art dealer who fled the Nazis.
content: For years, a large, richly colored painting depicting a moment of sexual violence has stopped visitors in Gallery 634 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: Republican Senators Tried to Stop Trump From Firing Impeachment Witness
description: A handful of senators reached out to the White House to warn the president not to dismiss Gordon D. Sondland, the ambassador to the European Union who testified in the House hearings. But Mr. Trump went ahead anyway.
content: WASHINGTON — A handful of Republican senators tried to stop President Trump from firing Gordon D. Sondland, the ambassador to the European Union who testified in the House impeachment hearings, but the president relieved the diplomat of his post anyway, according to people briefed on the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Antarctica Sets Record High Temperature: 64.9 Degrees
description: “This is the foreshadowing of what is to come,” a researcher said. “It’s exactly in line of what we’ve been seeing for decades.”
content: Antarctica, the coldest, windiest and driest continent on Earth, set a record high temperature on Thursday, underscoring the global warming trend, researchers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Sinn Fein Surges in Irish Elections, Exit Polls Predict
description: The faction formerly linked to the Irish Republican Army is expected to get an equal share of votes to Prime Minister Leo Varadkar’s party and the main opposition group.
content: Support for Sinn Fein, the former political wing of the Irish Republican Army, surged in Ireland’s national elections on Saturday, according to exit polls. Prime Minister Leo Varadkar’s party, in power since 2011, was weakened but the result left open the possibility that he could still hold onto his office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisann McLane
title: The Coronavirus Hits Hong Kong? Quick, Toilet Paper!
description: The irrational comforts of a panic-shopping spree.
content: HONG KONG — “It’s gone,” I overheard my neighbor Mrs. Wong shout in Cantonese from her balcony to a man on a bicycle downstairs. “Maai saai la!” Sold out.
source.name: The New York Times
